prompt:
Teacher:In this task, you are given a text of many news articles seperated by special token "|||||". Your task is to summarize them.
Teacher: Now, understand the problem? Solve this instance: Kentucky county clerk Kim Davis says a private meeting with Pope Francis has inspired her -– and given her a renewed sense of purpose. 
  
 Interested in ? Add as an interest to stay up to date on the latest news, video, and analysis from ABC News. Add Interest 
  
 “I was crying. I had tears coming out of my eyes,” Davis said in an exclusive interview with ABC News. “I'm just a nobody, so it was really humbling to think he would want to meet or know me.” 
  
 Davis, who refused to issue marriage licenses to same-sex couples, says the private meeting occurred during the pope’s historic trip to the United States. After receiving a surprise phone call from a church official, the Kentucky county clerk says she traveled to Washington, D.C., where she and her husband Joe met the pope Sept. 24 at the Vatican Embassy. 
  
 “I put my hand out and he reached and he grabbed it, and I hugged him and he hugged me,” Davis said. “And he said, ‘thank you for your courage.’” 
  
 Father Benedettini from the Vatican Press office released a statement after reports emerged that Davis and the pope had met. 
  
 “The Holy See is aware of the reports of Kim Davis meeting with the Holy Father. The Vatican does not confirm the meeting, nor does it deny the meeting. There will be no further information given,“ the statement reads. 
  
 Hours later, Father Benedettini said, in another statement, “I do not deny that the meeting took place, but I will not comment on it further." 
  
 The Apostolic Nunciature in Washington, D.C. would also not elaborate, echoing the Vatican's latest statement. 
  
 Liberty Counsel 
  
 Davis drew national attention -– and spent six days in jail -– after refusing a judge's order to issue marriage licenses in Rowan County, Kentucky, to same-sex and heterosexual couples, citing her religious beliefs. 
  
 Davis, back at work, is still not issuing any marriage licenses. 
  
 ABC News' Terry Moran asked Francis Sunday night if he supports individuals, including government officials, who claim religious liberty as a reason to disobey the law. 
  
 Francis responded, "I can't have in mind all the cases that can exist about conscientious objection, but, yes, I can say that conscientious objection is a right that is a part of every human right. It is a right. And if a person does not allow others to be a conscientious objector, he denies a right." 
  
 When asked if that includes government officials, Francis said, "It is a human right and if a government official is a human person, he has that right. It is a human right." 
  
 Davis says Pope Francis left her and her husband with a rosary. 
  
 “He told me before he left, he said, ‘stay strong.’ That was a great encouragement. Just knowing that the pope is on track with what we're doing, it kind of validates everything to have someone of that stature,” Davis said. 
  
 Davis says she’s committed to her cause, even if it means more time behind bars. 
  
 “I've weighed the cost and I'm prepared to do whatever it takes, even jail,” she said. “It's still the same battle, we just have some more fighting with us now.” ||||| Sep 29, 2015 
  
 Washington, DC – Media is buzzing about the Pope’s comments in support of conscientious objection and whether he knows about the Rowan County, Kentucky, Clerk of Court who was jailed for six days for refusing to issue same-sex marriage licenses. The Pope met privately with Kim Davis and her husband, Joe, at the Vatican Embassy in Washington, D.C., on Thursday, September 24, which was the birthday of Kim’s father. Pope Francis spoke with Kim and Joe Davis in English. 
  
 During the meeting Pope Francis said, "Thank you for your courage." Pope Francis also told Kim Davis, "Stay strong. He held out his hands and asked Kim to pray for him. Kim held his hands and said, "I will. Please pray for me," and the Pope said he would. The two embraced. The Pontiff presented Kim and Joe Davis each with a Rosary that he personally blessed. Kim's mother and father are Catholic, and Kim and Joe will present the Rosaries to her parents. Kim's mother was the elected Clerk of Court for Rowan County for 37 years until her retirement in 2014. 
  
 Kim Davis said, "I was humbled to meet Pope Francis. Of all people, why me?" Davis continued, "I never thought I would meet the Pope. Who am I to have this rare opportunity? I am just a County Clerk who loves Jesus and desires with all my heart to serve him." Kim said, "Pope Francis was kind, genuinely caring, and very personable. He even asked me to pray for him. Pope Francis thanked me for my courage and told me to 'stay strong.'" 
  
 "The challenges we face in America regarding the sanctity of human life, marriage, and religious freedom are the same universal challenges Christians face around the world. Religious freedom is a human right that comes from God. These values are shared in common by people of faith, and the threats to religious freedom are universal. Kim Davis has become a symbol of this worldwide conflict between Christian faith and recent cultural challenges regarding marriage," said Mat Staver, Founder and Chairman of Liberty Counsel. 
  
 Speaking with reporters on board the Papal plane to Rome, Pope Francis told Terry Moran of ABC News that conscientious objection is a human right, even for government officials: "Conscientious objection is a right that is a part of every human right. It is a right. And if a person does not allow others to be a conscientious objector, he denies a right. Conscientious objection must enter into every juridical structure because it is a right, a human right. Otherwise we would end up in a situation where we select what is a right, saying 'this right that has merit, this one does not.' It (conscientious objection) is a human right. It always moved me when I read, and I read it many times, when I read the "Chanson de Roland" when the people were all in line and before them was the baptismal font and they had to choose between the baptismal font or the sword. They had to choose. They weren't permitted conscientious objection. It is a right and if we want to make peace we have to respect all rights." 
  
 The ABC News Chief Foreign Correspondent asked if that includes government officials as well, and the Pope reiterated that conscientious objection is a human right: "It is a human right and if a government official is a human person, he has that right," Pope Francis affirmed. 
  
 After the above statement of Pope Francis was published, some in the media wondered if the Pontiff knew of Kim Davis. "Not only did Pope Francis know of Kim Davis, he personally met with her to express his support," concluded Staver. 
  
 Liberty Counsel is an international nonprofit, litigation, education, and policy organization dedicated to advancing religious freedom, the sanctity of life, and the family since 1989, by providing pro bono assistance and representation on these and related topics. 
  
 ### |||||
Student:
response: Kim Davis, a county clerk in Kentucky, gained national attention for refusing to issue marriage licenses to same-sex couples, citing her religious beliefs. This action led to her spending six days in jail. Despite being back at work, she continues not to issue marriage licenses and claims she's willing to face more jail time for her cause. Davis reported having had a private meeting with Pope Francis during his visit to the United States, claiming he commended her for her courage, encouraged her to stay strong, and gifted her and her husband a rosary. However, the Vatican Press Office has neither confirmed nor denied the meeting. Pope Francis was asked if he supports individuals, including government officials, who claim religious liberty as a reason to break the law, responding with a general affirmation of the right to conscientious objection.

prompt:
Given the question: What is the final step of the following process: -  Sunlight shines on plants - Cells with chlorophyll in them capture the light energy - Plants absorb carbon dioxide through their stoma - Plants absorb water through their roots and other parts of themselves - Plants absorb minerals through their roots - Plants convert these inputs into sugars - Sugars can be used as energy sources - Oxygen and water are also produced
The answer is:
response:
The final step of this process is the release of oxygen and water as by-products.

To recap the whole process and better understand the final step, let's break down the entire process of photosynthesis, which takes place in the following steps:

1. Sunlight shines on plants: Photosynthesis begins with the absorption of light energy by chlorophyll pigments within the chloroplasts of plant cells. Sunlight is the primary source of energy for this process.

2. Cells with chlorophyll capture the light energy: Chlorophyll pigments trap the light energy and convert it into chemical energy within the plants' cells.

3. Plants absorb carbon dioxide through their stomata: Stomata are tiny openings on the surface of plant leaves that facilitate gas exchange. Plants take in carbon dioxide from the surrounding atmosphere through these stomatal pores.

4. Plants absorb water through their roots and other parts: Water is taken up by the roots and transported through the vascular tissues, called xylem, to the different parts of the plant to maintain overall plant hydration and support various cellular processes.

5. Plants absorb minerals through their roots: Along with water, minerals and nutrients like nitrogen, phosphorous, and potassium are absorbed by plants through their roots from the soil. These nutrients are vital for various physiological processes within plants, including photosynthesis.

6. Plants convert these inputs into sugars: Once all the required inputs are absorbed by the plant, the process of photosynthesis commences. The chemical energy captured by chlorophyll, along with water, carbon dioxide, and minerals, is used to produce glucose (sugar) molecules through a series of complex chemical reactions. The glucose molecules serve as a primary energy source for plants, allowing them to grow, develop, and reproduce.

7. Sugars can be used as energy sources: The glucose produced through photosynthesis is either utilized immediately to fuel various metabolic processes within the plant or converted into complex carbohydrates (such as starch and cellulose) and stored for later use.

8. Oxygen and water are produced: As the final step of the process, oxygen and water are released as by-products of photosynthesis. The oxygen produced during photosynthesis is released through the same stomata used to absorb carbon dioxide, ultimately benefiting the entire ecosystem by providing a vital oxygen source for a plethora of life forms, including humans and other animals.

Thus, the final step involves the release of oxygen and water as by-products of the photosynthesis process, which not only completes the process but also plays a crucial role in maintaining the ecological balance on our planet.

prompt:
A Slew of Staph Infections Tackles the NFL
The NFL is learning the hard way that a microscopic foe can be much more imposing than a 300-pound lineman, as a sudden slew of staph infections has sacked several players in the game.

Early this week, Cleveland Browns tight end Kellen Winslow Jr. revealed that staph (short for Staphylococcus) infection had sent him to the Cleveland Clinic for three days, and he accused the Browns of asking him to cover it up. Pro football teams are notoriously reluctant to reveal any information on player injuries, but since six different Browns have caught the bug since 2005  Winslow has had it twice  the team's medical management looked suspect to some observers. "There's obviously a problem [with staph] and we have to fix it," Winslow told the Cleveland Plain Dealer. "Just look at the history around here. It's unfortunate, because it happens time and time again." The Browns, who denied that they had kept the news of his infection from his teammates, suspended Winslow one game for his rant, which included his claim that he felt like he had been treated like "a piece of meat."

But the Winslow medical controversy wasn't even the worst of it for the league. In the past week, it has become clear that two of its most marketable stars, marquee quarterbacks Tom Brady and Peyton Manning, had gotten infections. The New England Patriots' Brady has had at least two additional infection-related procedures since his initial season-ending knee surgery in September. It's now possible that his knee will have to undergo another operation, which could delay his return until 2010. Staph seems to be the likely culprit, but neither Brady nor the Patriots will confirm that. During training camp staph infected a bursa sac, which acts as a cushion between bones, in Manning's left knee. The infection required surgery and forced him to miss most of the preseason. Though the Colts released a statement on Friday insisting Manning didn't contract a more perilous staph, the anti-biotic resistant strain known as MRSA (methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus), the incidents should alarm the NFL. "The NFL, and all the leagues, should be diligent, and not let their guards down," says Dr. Robert Gotlin, director of Orthopedic and Sports Rehabilitation at Beth Israel Medical Center in New York City. "They've got to do better. It's got to be one of the top five priorities."

The recent cases have certainly gotten players' attention. "I'm concerned, and wondering why it's happening. It's not some little infection that goes away in a few days, it's pretty serious," says Chicago Bears rookie running back Matt Forte. The league is quick to point out that it has partnered with teams to educate players about the bacteria, while the players' union insists it's alarmed and has contacted the league about further action. Some teams, like the Colts, have posted pictures on training room walls that warn players about staph symptoms and how to avoid contracting or spreading it. For their part, the Browns note that the team has previously used a special anti-staph agent to disinfect the locker room, weight room and other places where players gather.

Staph, of course, is far from just an NFL problem. Two college teams, the '05 Florida Gators and the '03 USC Trojans, had multiple cases. And football is by no means the only sports victim. The infection kept Toronto Blue Jays outfielder Alex Rios out of the 2006 All-Star Game. A few days later another Toronto player caught it, and the clubhouse was disinfected. NBA players Paul Pierce, Grant Hill and Drew Gooden have had it. Staph killed a high school wrestler in California this summer, and last spring 15 students at a Pennsylvania high school were either treated for staph or symptoms caused by the virus.

What exactly are staph infections? Staph is bacteria carried on the skin, which can enter the body through a cut or during a medical procedure, causing the infection. Most are minor, but certain strains are particularly resistant to anti-biotics and can cause athletes to miss significant playing time. Athletes are more likely to suffer cuts, and the locker room setting bunches players close to one another in a warm, damp environment, so they are especially susceptible to spreading the bacteria. Since football teams carry some 55 players on their rosters, and tend to have a higher degree of serious injuries to deal with, they are at particular risk. According to a 2005 survey by the NFL Team Physicians Society, 13 out of 30 teams that responded had had a player contract MRSA in recent years, for a total of 60 leaguewide infections.

Though Philadelphia Eagles linebacker Omar Gaither rightly points out that "we're just a naturally dirty sport," there are several basic precautions athletes can take to lower the chance of catching an infection. Many athletes shave their ankles, legs, and arms because they don't want athletic tape ripping hair off their bodies, but experts say they should lose the razor. "No matter how careful the shaving is, you can have nicks and microscopic cuts in the skin," says Dr. Daniel Sexton, an infectious disease specialist at the Duke University Medical Center, who consults for an NFL team and several college programs. "Any time you break that barrier, it becomes a portal through which bacteria can gain access." Staph prevention is pretty low-tech. "You know, this is pretty simple," Sexton says. "Hand washing remains the primary defense against the transmissions of most organisms, including staph. Most people don't think of a locker room as a place where hand hygiene is important, but locker rooms are also mini-emergency rooms."

In 2003, a team of researchers tracked the St. Louis Rams and found five players who caught eight MRSA infections. "We observed a lack of regular access to hand hygiene (i.e., soap and water or alcohol-based hand gels) for trainers who provided wound care," they wrote in The New England Journal of Medicine. Other offenses included "skipping of showers by players before the use of communal whirlpools; and sharing or towels  all factors that might facilitate the transmission of infection in this setting."

In short: use a little common sense, tough guys. But when it comes to infectious germs, even a 245-lb. bruiser like Gaither believes you can't always outrun them. "You can't worry about it to death," he says. "It's not like you can walk around and put gloves on your hand every 10 seconds. Sometimes, there's just not that much you can do." Except hope that these recent cases are a coincidental hiccup, and not an epidemic that seriously tackles the NFL.

(See pictures of the week here.)
What was this article about?
response: This article discusses the issue of staph infections becoming a growing concern in the NFL. Several players, including Cleveland Browns' tight end Kellen Winslow Jr., New England Patriots' Tom Brady, and Indianapolis Colts' Peyton Manning, have contracted infections due to Staphylococcus (staph) bacteria in recent years. The article highlights the possible reasons behind the spread of these infections, such as the warm, damp environment of locker rooms, large team rosters allowing for easier transmission, and athletes being more susceptible to cuts and infection entry points. Precautions and preventive measures are also discussed, emphasizing the importance of hand hygiene and not sharing towels or other personal items. The concern extends beyond the NFL, as staph infections have also plagued college football teams and athletes in other sports. The article calls for improved preventive strategies and education about staph infections in the league to protect players and prevent a potential epidemic affecting the NFL.

prompt: Michael has $42. Michael gives away half the money to his brother. His brother then buys 3 dollars worth of candy. If his brother has $35 left, how much money, in dollars, did his brother have at first? Let's answer step by step:
response:
Step 1: Determine how much money Michael gave to his brother.
Michael had $42 and gave away half of it, so we need to find half of $42.
$42 ÷ 2 = $21

So, Michael gave his brother $21.

Step 2: Determine how much money his brother had after receiving the money from Michael.
His brother bought $3 worth of candy after receiving the $21 from Michael. To find out how much money he had after buying the candy, we'll subtract $3 from $21.
$21 - $3 = $18

So, after buying the candy, his brother had $18.

Step 3: Determine how much money his brother had at first.
Since his brother now has $35 left, and he had $18 after buying the candy, we need to find out how much his brother had initially before receiving money from Michael and buying the candy. We will add this initial amount to the $18 to get $35.
Initial amount + $18 = $35

To find the initial amount, we'll subtract $18 from $35.
$35 - $18 = $17

Therefore, his brother initially had $17.

Q:Combine facts and answer this: The most notable personality on "NBC Talknet" apart from Bruce Williams has what nationality?
A:
response:
To answer this question, it is important to first understand what "NBC Talknet" is and get familiar with some of its notable personalities. Then, we can accurately identify their nationalities and single out the most notable personality apart from Bruce Williams.

NBC Talknet was an American radio network which started in 1981 and focused on advice-oriented talk shows. It was launched by NBC Radio Networks, a division of National Broadcasting Company (NBC). Talknet made a significant impact in North American radio, increasing popularity for advice shows featuring expert hosts engaging directly with callers, creating a community-like atmosphere. Bruce Williams, an American radio host, was one of the most significant personalities that aired on NBC Talknet.

Bruce Williams hosted "The Bruce Williams Show," which became a popular call-in show on the network. He had a background in business and was known for offering practical advice to his callers on various topics including personal finance, career, and life in general. Unfortunately, Bruce Williams passed away in 2019.

Apart from Bruce Williams, another notable personality on NBC Talknet was Sally Jessy Raphael, also an American radio and television talk show host. Raphael hosted a call-in advice show on NBC Talknet called "The Sally Jessy Raphael Show," which later transitioned into a syndicated TV talk show under the title "Sally."

Sally Jessy Raphael was born in Easton, Pennsylvania, U.S., making her nationality American. Raphael has had a remarkable career in the radio and television industries, which spanned for over 30 years, garnering a large fan following and multiple prestigious awards. She retired from her television show in 2002 but continued working in the radio broadcasting segment.

In conclusion, the most notable personality on "NBC Talknet" apart from Bruce Williams is Sally Jessy Raphael, who holds an American nationality. Both Bruce Williams and Sally Jessy Raphael were famous for their call-in advice shows and had a significant impact on North American radio, shaping the community-like atmosphere that Talknet provided to its audience.

James could not hear the sound of his television in his neighborhood because the
response:
James could not hear the sound of his television in his neighborhood because the overall noise levels and disturbances emanating from various sources combined to create a densely cacophonous environment that rendered his auditory senses incapable of discerning the audio output from his television. This situation may have arisen due to several contributing factors, each amplifying the auditory chaos that enveloped the vicinity of his residence.

Firstly, the neighborhood itself might be closely packed with houses and apartments, fostering a condensed living arrangement where the walls and barriers provide minimal insulation against the sounds produced by the inhabitants. As a consequence, mundane domestic activities like conversing, playing music, or utilizing appliances would reverberate throughout the locale, generating an incessant background noise that could easily overwhelm James's television audio.

Moreover, it is highly plausible that large numbers of pedestrians and street traffic contribute to the heightened noise levels in the area. The constant hustle and bustle of people going about their daily lives, running errands, or engaging in conversations could lead to a cacophony of voices and footsteps. Additionally, a busy street with a steady flow of cars, buses, motorcycles, and other vehicles adds another layer of disturbance to the audioscape. The emissions arising from engines, honks, brakes, and steady whooshes of passing automobiles exacerbate the noise pollution affecting James's ability to hear his television clearly.

Beyond the immediate residential and street scenarios, James's neighborhood could also be exposed to intrusive noise influxes originating from commercial establishments and ongoing construction work. Restaurants and pubs, usually found in populated areas, might host patrons who partake in lively discussions or even boisterous revelry, generating substantial noise spillage. Similarly, live music venues, nightclubs, or other entertainment options contribute significantly to the din pervading the surroundings. Meanwhile, ongoing construction projects in the vicinity – be it new developments, renovations, or infrastructure improvements – generate hammering, drilling, and machinery noises that could further impede James's efforts to hear his television.

Lastly, James's neighborhood might be located near prominent noise sources, such as railroads, airports, or busy highways. The relentless stream of noise generated by trains, planes, or incessant road traffic would ultimately deprive the area of any semblance of peace and quiet. Consequently, the compounded acoustic chaos radiating from these disparate sources would obliterate the possibility of making out the television's audio output amidst the prevailing noise pollution.

In conclusion, James's struggle to hear his television in his neighborhood arises from a range of factors that culminate in an inescapable cacophony. To address this issue, he might consider investing in noise-canceling headphones, soundproofing his residence, or opting for alternate entertainment methods like streaming services with subtitles, which can potentially alleviate the frustration caused by his audibility predicament.

Bea, a five-year-old girl, was born with a severe illness which means she has to be kept away from other children of her age, because her body is so weak that she would be unable to fight off a common cold. Bea was diagnosed with this disease when she was five months old. Since then, the hospital has become her second home, medicines for food, and all kinds of treatments her friends. Bea received a very special treatment when she was four years old, which would allow her to be like a normal child if successful. After that, she spent two weeks in ICU before living for four months on a separate ward . Bea was allowed home in February but still needed a special tube in her nose to send in medicines every two days. Her parents clean the house from top to bottom every two days and hoover each morning to make sure Bea is free from any possible bacteria. Anna, Bea's mother, said, "she is weak but so strong. We've never seen any child stronger than her. It seems as if nothing in the world could beat her. We really hope to send her to school next year." She used to drive on the local playground, but Bea was only allowed to watch sitting in the car. "It was heartbreaking to see Bea staring at the running and laughing children there. The answer to this question is:
response: C) Her life would be in great danger as she could fall ill easily. While being able to play and socialize with other children freely would certainly contribute to her happiness, it could also expose her to harmful germs and diseases, thus severely endangering her life. Despite the many treatments she has undergone, Bea's immune system is not strong enough to combat common illnesses effectively. Therefore, her interaction with the outside world has to be strictly controlled and monitored.

prompt:
Read this: Nearly all polychaetes have parapodia that function as limbs, while other major annelid groups lack them. Parapodia are unjointed paired extensions of the body wall, and their muscles are derived from the circular muscles of the body. They are often supported internally by one or more large, thick chetae. The parapodia of burrowing and tube-dwelling polychaetes are often just ridges whose tips bear hooked chetae. In active crawlers and swimmers the parapodia are often divided into large upper and lower paddles on a very short trunk, and the paddles are generally fringed with chetae and sometimes with cirri (fused bundles of cilia) and gills.

What kind of parapodia do burrowing annelids often have?
What is the answer? (If it cannot be answered, return "unanswerable")
response: Burrowing annelids often have parapodia that are just ridges whose tips bear hooked chetae.

prompt:
Write a summary based on this article:

A strange and surprising report emerges from Avignon, where Catholic activists protested at the Museum of Contemporary Art and, rather than merely demonstrating against a work they considered blasphemous (as they had done on Saturday), actually destroyed it. Pierre Haski reports at Rue 89: 
  
 Sunday, Palm Sunday in Catholic tradition, the protesters were more aggressive: two people managed to get into the museum and to strike at art works with hammers that they concealed in their clothing. No one was arrested at the time, but, according to the director of the museum, who was interviewed on France Culture [a radio station], two people had already been identified from photos taken at Saturday’s protest and are being sought by the police. 
  
 One of the works they destroyed was Andres Serrano’s 1987 photograph “Piss Christ,” which, Haski writes, was “displayed two years ago at the Pompidou Center without making waves.” But, of course, Paris isn’t Avignon—the seat of the papacy in the fourteenth century. The organization behind the protest, Civitas (“for a Catholic city”), expressly seeks “the restoration of the social reign of Jesus Christ over civil society.” 
  
 In 1989, Serrano’s photograph became an object of national controversy here when it was shown in an exhibit in North Carolina. At the time, I was working as an editorial factotum to Edward de Grazia, a professor at the Cardozo School of Law, as he was completing his magisterial book about the recent history of censorship (mainly) in the United States, “Girls Lean Back Everywhere.” He discusses the controversy in the book. Serrano and his work were denounced on the floor of Congress by New York’s Senator Alfonse D’Amato and by North Carolina’s Senator Jesse Helms (“I do not know Mr. Andres Serrano, and I hope I never meet him because he is not an artist, he is a jerk”). It resulted in funding cuts to the National Endowment for the Arts, which had partially financed the show in which the photo was included—as well as in a bill to prevent the N.E.A. from funding art works that “denigrate the objects or beliefs of the adherents of a particular religion or nonreligion.” But the photograph wasn’t destroyed. 
  
 I’m reminded of the difference between screenings of Jean-Luc Godard’s “Hail Mary” in France in January, 1985 (advance screenings there were interrupted by protesters who threw stink bombs, and a reel of the film was stolen from a projection booth), and its screening here at the New York Film Festival later that year (protesters arrived by the busload and blocked the streets in front of Alice Tully Hall, but the police cordoned off a corridor to allow ticket-holders to pass, and the screening took place unimpeded). In 1988, movie theatres in France showing Martin Scorsese’s film “The Last Temptation of Christ” were vandalized—including by Molotov cocktail and tear gas—and spectators were assaulted by Catholic fundamentalists. ||||| Image caption There had been protests against the work the day before the attack 
  
 A controversial photograph of a crucifix bathed in urine has been vandalised at an art museum in southern France, officials said. 
  
 The work, Piss Christ, by American artist Andres Serrano, was attacked on Sunday by three vandals who also threatened staff at the museum in Avignon. 
  
 A demonstration against the photograph drew some 800 protesters on Saturday. 
  
 The work also proved contentious in the US when it was first displayed in 1989. 
  
 Protests 
  
 Police said two people had attempted to enter the Collection Lambert art museum on Sunday morning with paint spray and a chisel in their jackets. 
  
 As a guard was removing the items, a third person took a hammer to the work, according the Associated Press. 
  
 The museum said in a statement the vandals physically threatened three guards before fleeing. 
  
 A second work, The Church, the torso of a nun with her hands in her lap, was also damaged. 
  
 On Saturday, a right-wing group held a protest to denounce the photograph as blasphemous and to call for its removal. 
  
 One museum worker told Reuters news agency they had received death threats by phone. 
  
 "We're nervous and we have asked for protection from the police," the employee said. 
  
 The museum said the exhibition, entitled I Believe In Miracles, would be open as usual on Tuesday with the damaged works on show. |||||

Summary:
response:
A controversial artwork, "Piss Christ" by American artist Andres Serrano, was destroyed during a protest by Catholic activists at the Museum of Contemporary Art in Avignon, France. The 1987 photograph which depicts a crucifix bathed in urine, has been a subject of controversy since its creation. The protesters managed to enter the museum on Palm Sunday and struck the artwork with hammers they had concealed in their clothing. The director of the museum stated that two people had already been identified from photos taken at Saturday's protest and are being sought by the police.

The organization behind the protest, Civitas, seeks "the restoration of the social reign of Jesus Christ over civil society." In 1989, the photograph sparked outrage when it was shown in an exhibit in North Carolina and led to funding cuts to the National Endowment for the Arts, which had partially financed the show in which the photo was included. However, this is the first time the photograph has been physically destroyed.

This event highlights the ongoing debate over the line between artistic expression and the potential for offense to religious beliefs.

prompt:
Stimuloitu emissio

Could you please translate this to English?
response:
"Stimuloitu emissio" is a Finnish term that translates to "stimulated emission" in English. 

Stimulated emission is a quantum mechanical process in which a particle, such as an electron or an atom, is induced to emit radiation by external factors, such as the interaction with electromagnetic fields. This process is a significant aspect of lasers (Light Amplification by Stimulated Emission of Radiation) and masers (Microwave Amplification by Stimulated Emission of Radiation) technologies.

In these devices, a population of particles is excited to a higher energy level through various methods, such as illumination with light or electrical pumping. When an incoming photon interacts with an excited particle (atom or molecule), the particle may be stimulated to emit an additional photon with the same energy (wavelength), phase, and direction as the incoming photon. This process of photon-induced emission is called stimulated emission. As more emitted photons interact with other excited particles, a chain reaction occurs, and the process continues, amplifying the intensity of light or electromagnetic radiation.

The concept of stimulated emission was first proposed by Albert Einstein in 1917, but it wasn't until the 1950s and 1960s that it led to the development of masers and lasers. Lasers have diverse applications in various fields, including medicine, telecommunications, entertainment, military, and scientific research.

In summary, "stimuloitu emissio" translates to "stimulated emission" in English, a fundamental principle in the functioning of lasers and masers, which contribute significantly to technology and advancements in numerous fields.

I firmly intend, with your help,to do penance, to sin no more, andto avoid whatever leads me to sin.Our Savior Jesus Christ suffered and died for us.In his name, my God, have mercy  (If you are a Roman Catholic, your act of contrition will go like this: Oh my God, I am very sorry for having offended thee. prompt:
-  Air enters bronchioles - Bronchioles have tiny air sacs called alveoli - Alveoli surrounded by small blood vessels - Oxygen absorbed by small blood vessels - Vessels deliver oxygen to every cell in the body - Blood brings carbon dioxide back to lungs - Carbon dioxide released when you exhale.  What might be the first step of the process?
A:
response:
The first step of the process is the inhalation of air. When you breathe in, air travels through various parts of your respiratory system before reaching the bronchioles. Here's a more detailed breakdown of the entire process:

1. Inhalation: The process starts with inhalation, during which air is drawn into the body through the nose or mouth. The hairs and mucous membranes in the nasal cavity help to filter out any large particles or debris present in the inhaled air.

2. Pharynx and larynx: After passing through the nasal cavity or mouth, the air travels down the throat, or pharynx, and then through the voice box, or larynx.

3. Trachea: The air continues its journey through the trachea or windpipe, which is a long tube that leads from the larynx to the bronchi. The trachea has a series of tiny hair-like structures called cilia, which help to trap any particles that may have entered the airway, preventing them from reaching the lower respiratory system.

4. Bronchi: The trachea branches into two tubes known as bronchi - the left bronchus and the right bronchus. Each bronchus enters a respective lung and further subdivides into smaller branches called bronchioles.

5. Bronchioles: As mentioned in the initial explanation, air travels through bronchioles, which contain tiny air sacs called alveoli.

6. Alveoli: Oxygen from the inhaled air diffuses across the thin walls of the alveoli into the surrounding small blood vessels, called capillaries. Simultaneously, carbon dioxide, a waste byproduct of cellular metabolism, diffuses from the blood into the alveoli.

7. Oxygen transport: Oxygen-rich blood from the capillaries is transported by the circulatory system, delivering oxygen to every cell in the body.

8. Carbon dioxide removal: Blood containing higher levels of carbon dioxide is brought back to the lungs by the circulatory system. The carbon dioxide diffuses into the alveoli and is expelled from the body when you exhale.

2. "Cast off for the first buttonhole on the right band": "Casting off" is a knitting technique that is used to close off the stitches in order to create a finished edge. It is also called "binding off" and is commonly used in the final step of finishing a knitting project. In this particular case, you'll be using the cast-off technique to create the buttonhole on the right band of your knitting.

3. "Read explanation above": The provided instructions assume that there is an explanation given previously within your knitting pattern that details how to create the buttonhole. In summary, when your knitting piece measures the appropriate length (6-6-7 or 7-7 cm) based on the project you're working on, you should cast off to create your first buttonhole on the right band. prompt:
Danielle Deaver, 34, wanted an abortion after doctors told her that her baby had no chance of surviving when her waters broke at 22 weeks. A new law in Nebraska which dictates that you cannot have an abortion after 20 weeks meant Deaver had no choice but to have her baby. With her husband, Robb, the couple waited ten days until she was able to give birth to baby Elizabeth. The couple cradled and comforted their baby for 15 minutes before she died.

Write an article based on these highlights.
response:
Title: Heartbreaking Story of Woman Denied Abortion Under Nebraska's New Law

Subtitle: Danielle Deaver Forced to Deliver Doomed Baby under Controversial Legislation

In a tragic case that has reignited the debate on abortion rights in the United States, 34-year-old Danielle Deaver was denied an abortion after her waters broke at just 22 weeks, forcing her to carry her baby to full term, who ultimately survived for only 15 minutes after being born. The reason behind this heart-wrenching decision was Nebraska's new 20-week abortion ban, which left Deaver with no choice but to endure the devastating outcome.

The doctors informed Danielle Deaver that her baby had no chance of survival after her amniotic sac ruptured at 22 weeks, leaving the fetus without the necessary protection and nourishing fluid to develop in the womb. In the past, medical professionals would have recommended an abortion in such cases, given the cruelty of making the mother and child suffer through an event that would ultimately culminate in the heartache of death. However, Nebraska's recent law change meant that Deaver's hands were tied, and she could not terminate her pregnancy after the 20-week mark.

With the support of her husband Robb, Deaver spent the next ten agonizing days waiting to deliver her child, knowing that there was no hope of survival. In an interview, Robb commented about how they knew their baby would not live, and they tried preparing themselves for the moment that would come. The couple's worst fears were realized when Danielle gave birth to their baby girl, Elizabeth, who survived for a brief 15 minutes cuddled in her parents' arms before passing away.

This tragic story raises several pressing questions not just about Nebraska's abortion laws but also regarding reproductive rights in the United States as a whole. The 20-week ban enacted in Nebraska, known as the "Pain-Capable Unborn Child Protection Act," has been challenged by many in the medical and legal fields who believe that it is fundamentally flawed.

Critics argue that the law fails to take into account exceptional circumstances, such as those experienced by the Deaver family, which result in the prolonged suffering of both mother and baby. Furthermore, opinions on when a fetus can feel pain remain divided among experts, leading some to view the time limit as arbitrary.

In a country where debate rages over abortion accessibility and a woman's right to choose, Danielle Deaver's heartrending experience serves as a painful reminder of the consequences legislation can have on the lives of real people. As lawmakers continue to grapple with contentious issues surrounding reproductive rights, stories like this one put a human face on the impact that such regulations have on families and their personal journeys.

One cannot help but question if rigid laws should be the final arbiter in deeply complex and individual cases such as Deaver's. What remains certain, however, is that the ripples from this tragic case will continue to be felt in the ongoing debate surrounding reproductive rights and the ethical considerations of abortion laws in the United States.

prompt:
Sentence: "Mary loves him."
Would a linguist rate this sentence to be acceptable linguistically?
response:
A linguist would likely rate the sentence "Mary loves him" as acceptable linguistically, based on several linguistic principles and components. To provide a detailed explanation, let's breakdown the key linguistic aspects that contribute to the acceptability of this sentence.

1. Syntax: Syntax refers to the rules that govern the structure of sentences in a language. In English, the typical word order follows a Subject-Verb-Object (SVO) pattern. In the sentence "Mary loves him," the subject (Mary) is followed by the verb (loves) and the object (him). This structure adheres to the SVO pattern, making the sentence syntactically acceptable.

2. Grammar: Grammar encompasses the rules governing the construction of phrases, clauses, and sentences in a language. When examining the grammar of this sentence, we observe that the verb "loves" agrees with the subject "Mary" in both number (singular) and person (third person). The verb is also in the present tense, which is appropriate for describing an ongoing action or state. The pronoun "him" serves as the direct object, and it is used correctly to refer to a male person. Thus, the sentence is grammatically acceptable.

3. Semantics: Semantics deals with the meanings of words, phrases, and sentences in a language. In this sentence, "Mary" is a proper noun and denotes a particular person. The verb "loves" carries a clear meaning, expressing a strong affection or emotional bond between the subject and object. The pronoun "him" is used to refer to a male person, and its meaning is context-dependent; it relies on the presence of an antecedent, which is not provided in this sentence. However, this is common in standalone sentences and does not make it unacceptable linguistically. The semantics of the sentence are therefore understandable and convey a clear message.

4. Morphology: Morphology pertains to the study of the internal structure of words and how they are formed in a language. In this sentence, all the words are well-formed and appropriate for their respective roles. "Mary" is a proper noun, "loves" is formed by attaching the regular third-person singular suffix "-s" to the base form of the verb "love," and "him" is the correct form of the masculine pronoun used in the object position. Consequently, the sentence is morphologically acceptable.

5. Pragmatics: Pragmatics is concerned with the ways in which context influences the interpretation of meaning in a language. Although the sentence "Mary loves him" does not provide the broader context, such as whom "him" refers to or why Mary loves him, the sentence remains functionally communicative. Pragmatically, it allows the interlocutor to infer some specific information (Mary's feelings) and introduce further questions or conversation points to seek clarification of the missing context.

Taking into account these linguistic aspects, a linguist would generally rate the sentence "Mary loves him" as acceptable linguistically, as it adheres to the key principles of syntax, grammar, semantics, morphology, and basic pragmatic understanding.

prompt:
(CNN) -- Women seeking an abortion in Texas will have to view a picture of the embryo or fetus and hear a description of its development before having the procedure, under a law that takes effect September 1. The bill stirred some controversy in Texas, but it easily passed through the state House and Senate, both of which are controlled by Republicans. It was signed into law Thursday by Republican Gov. Rick Perry. The law says that at least 24 hours before an abortion is performed, women must undergo a sonogram, a procedure that uses ultrasound to create an image. The doctor, then, is required to give, "in a manner understandable to a layperson, a verbal explanation of the results of the sonogram images, including a medical description of the dimensions of the embryo or fetus, the presence of cardiac activity, and the presence of external members and internal organs," the law states. There are some exceptions, including pregnancies that resulted from sexual assault, incest or other violations of law. Women seeking abortions also are exempt if the fetus has been found to have an irreversible medical condition that will cause a disability. "Governor Perry was pleased to sign this important legislation, which bolsters our efforts to protect life by ensuring Texans are fully informed when considering such an important decision," said his deputy press secretary, Lucy Nashed. Critics say the new law is unnecessary. "What no one is focusing on is that this is a mandate to humiliate women who want an abortion," said Yvonne Gutierrez, vice president for public affairs at the Planned Parenthood Trust of South Texas. Texas already requires a 24-hour consent period, and the new law will simply add emotional and financial costs to those seeking abortions, she said. 

Question: "Why do critics feel the law is unnecessary?"

Answer: "Women who wane to get abortion will go to a different state"

Is this answer to the question correct?
OPTIONS:
(1). no
(2). yes
response:
(1). no

The answer mentioned is not correct because it does not address the reason why critics feel the law is unnecessary. The correct reason, as stated in the text, is that critics believe the law is a mandate to humiliate women who want an abortion, and it adds emotional and financial costs to those seeking abortions. The answer provided talks about women potentially going to a different state to get an abortion, which is not mentioned in the text as the reason critics find the law unnecessary.

prompt: Write a sentence not in English.
response:
"Per aspera ad astra" è una frase in latino che tradotta letteralmente significa "attraverso le asperità fino alle stelle". Questa espressione si riferisce al coraggio e alla perseveranza necessari per superare gli ostacoli nella vita e raggiungere obiettivi importanti, come metaforicamente raggiungere le stelle. Attraverso impegno e tenacia, possiamo affrontare le difficoltà e trovare la forza di superarle, raggiungendo alla fine le nostre aspirazioni più elevate.

Da notare che il latino è una lingua morta, tuttavia, è ancora utilizzata in contesti accademici, giuridici e religiosi. La frase "Per aspera ad astra" è stata anche usata come motto in molte istituzioni e organizzazioni in vari settori, come la scienza, l'esplorazione spaziale, e le arti, sottolineando la comune ricerca dell'umanità per la conoscenza, l'avanzamento, e lo sviluppo.

Nel corso della storia, il latino è stato ampiamente considerato una lingua prestigiosa associata all'erudizione e all'alta cultura. Durante il periodo dell'Impero romano, il latino era parlato da milioni di persone in Europa, Asia e Africa. Divenne anche la lingua franca degli intellettuali e delle classi dirigenti in Europa, e rimase in uso come lingua colta fino al XVIII secolo. 

Anche se il latino è una lingua che non viene più parlata come prima lingua da alcuna comunità, la sua influenza e il suo impatto sulle lingue moderne è ancora evidente. Ad esempio, il latino ha avuto un impatto significativo sulle lingue romanze come l'italiano, il francese, lo spagnolo e il portoghese, che sono tutte derivate in una certa misura dal latino vulgare. Molti termini nelle scienze, nella medicina, nella filosofia, nella religione e nelle arti provengono anche dal latino.

Inoltre, diverse espressioni latine come "Per aspera ad astra" sono state integrate nel linguaggio comune e continuano ad essere utilizzate per trasmettere saggezza e ispirazione. Questa particolare espressione, "Per aspera ad astra", ci ricorda l'importanza di perseverare di fronte alle difficoltà e di continuare a lavorare per il raggiungimento dei nostri obiettivi, nonostante gli ostacoli che possiamo incontrare lungo il cammino.

Problem: Solve -5*w = -0 - 20 for w.
And the answer is...
response:
Okay, little buddy! Let's solve this math problem together. We have:

-5 * w = -0 - 20

We want to find out what "w" is. To do that, we need to get "w" all by itself on one side of the equal sign. 

Right now, we have "-5" multiplied by "w". To get rid of the "-5", we'll do the opposite, which is dividing!

So, we'll divide both sides of the equation by -5:

(-5 * w) / -5 = (-20) / -5

Now, since the -5 on the left side of the equal sign cancels out, we're left with:

w = 4

And there you have it! The answer is w = 4. Great job, little buddy!

II. yes.

Quora, a popular question and answer platform, has implemented a word limit for questions and question descriptions for several reasons. The following factors contribute to the rationale behind Quora's decision to enforce these restrictions:

1. Clarity: Concise questions tend to be clearer and easier to understand. By imposing a word limit, Quora encourages users to focus on the essential components of their queries, ensuring that the questions posed are easy to read and comprehend. In turn, this facilitates more accurate responses from individuals who possess relevant knowledge or expertise in the subject matter.

2. User Experience: Restricting the length of questions and descriptions on Quora significantly improves the platform's user experience. By presenting brief, succinct questions, users can quickly scan and identify the topics that interest them or those to which they can contribute valuable insights. This increases user engagement, participation, and satisfaction on the platform.

3. Maintain Focused Conversations: Another critical aspect of implementing a word limit on Quora is the ability to maintain focused conversations around specific topics. By encouraging users to keep their questions concise and to the point, the platform minimizes the likelihood of numerous branching or unrelated discussions, which can often lead to confusion and dilute the value of the information exchange. As a result, Quora can better fulfill its role as an efficient knowledge-sharing platform.

4. Demands on Attention: In today's fast-paced and information-saturated world, people often have limited attention spans. Long and verbose questions have the potential to lose a reader's interest, leading them to bypass the question or miss essential details. By setting a word limit on questions and descriptions, Quora ensures that its platform remains engaging and accessible to a diverse user base.

5. Quality Control: A word limit encourages users to prioritize the quality of their questions over quantity. It discourages the use of excessive information or irrelevant details that could potentially derail a discussion or dilute the question's primary focus. This emphasis on quality helps ensure that Quora remains an effective platform for knowledge exchange.

In summary, the word limit for questions and question descriptions on Quora contributes significantly to the platform's functionality and user experience. Through these restrictions, Quora promotes concise, clear, and relevant questions that foster targeted and meaningful conversations among members of its community.

prompt:
Translate the following sentence to French:
For those of you who are reluctant about ordering online is now available as Furniturebox concept store.
response:
The objective is to translate the English sentence to French accurately. 

Therefore, my translation in French would be: 

"Pour ceux d'entre vous qui sont réticents à commander en ligne, il est désormais disponible en tant que magasin concept Furniturebox."

Let's break this down a little to justify the translation:

1. "For those of you who are reluctant" translates to "Pour ceux d'entre vous qui sont réticents". French treats plural forms and pronouns differently so "you" becomes "d'entre vous" instead of simple "vous".

2. "about ordering online" translates to "à commander en ligne". In French, the preposition "about" is translated to 'à' when referencing a particular subject or topic.

3. "is now available" translates to "est désormais disponible". The phrase "is now available" changes to "est désormais disponible", shifting the 'now' to be more formal ('désormais') than the literal translation of 'now' ('maintenant') in French to sound more natural.

4. "as Furniturebox concept store" it's translated to the natural phrase "en tant que magasin concept Furniturebox". The preposition 'as' translate to 'en tant que' in this context in French. The words 'Furniturebox', 'concept' and 'store' are all cognates and acceptable in French, particularly in the context of brand names and modern industry terminology.

Remembering this steps you can ensure a correct translation from English to French.

Hypothesis: "Two women are running down the streets."
Is the hypothesis entailed by the premise?
Options:
- yes
- it is not possible to tell
- no
Let's solve step-by-step:
response:
Step 1: Understand the premise and hypothesis
- Premise: "Two women waiting for the crosswalk light to turn green."
- Hypothesis: "Two women are running down the streets."

Step 2: Compare the premise and hypothesis
- The premise states that two women are waiting for the crosswalk light to turn green.
- The hypothesis states that two women are running down the streets.

Step 3: Check if the hypothesis is entailed by the premise
- In the premise, the women are waiting, which means they are stationary, while in the hypothesis, the women are running, which means they are in motion.

Step 4: Decide which option is correct
- The hypothesis and premise are contradictory, as the women are depicted in different states: waiting (stationary) versus running (motion).

Answer: NO. The hypothesis is not entailed by the premise.

Article: The host poured the tea into the cup and placed it on the small table in front of his guests, who were a father and daughter, and the cover on the cup. prompt:
Write a "positive" movie review (Available options:
* negative
* positive).
response:
Title: A Symphony of Joy - A Positive Movie Review

A Symphony of Joy is a film that splendidly captures the essence of human emotions while skilfully intertwining moments of pure joy, laughter, and a deep sense of triumph. It is a cinematic masterpiece that showcases the vast landscape of human experiences, leaving the audience with a renewed appreciation of the beauty of life. This positive movie review aims to celebrate the extraordinary journey that A Symphony of Joy takes us on and how it continues to inspire and uplift viewers of all ages.

At its core, the movie revolves around the interconnected lives of six diverse characters, each having their own personal challenges to face. The ensemble cast, led by the incredible talents of A-list actors, is phenomenal in bringing each character to life. Their performances are flawless, and the chemistry among the cast members is both heartwarming and spectacular, making their connections on screen feel genuine and palpable.

The film's director, a visionary and seasoned auteur, expertly weaves together the narratives of these characters, creating a beautifully crafted tapestry of human experiences. The cinematography is nothing short of breathtaking, as the director captures the essence of each character through intimate close-ups and striking landscapes that pose as visual metaphors for the emotional states of the characters. When combined with an enchanting musical score, A Symphony of Joy achieves an ethereal quality that immerses the audience into this complex world of emotions.

The script, written by a highly acclaimed screenwriter, is filled with thoughtful dialogue, subtle metaphors, and powerful, transformative moments that bring about profound change in the characters' lives. The movie's pacing and plot progression leave viewers engaged and emotionally invested, as they observe the characters navigate personal growth and self-discovery. One cannot help but feel a sense of kinship towards these characters, reflecting on their own lives and the universal human experiences that unite us all.

Throughout the film, a recurring theme of hope and resilience is evident in A Symphony of Joy. Each character faces their own unique set of struggles; however, it is their ability to find strength and hope from within their hardships that forms the crux of the story. Townsfolk and critics alike have praised the film for its honest portrayal of the challenges life can present and its insistence on hope's enduring presence, even in the darkest of times.

In conclusion, A Symphony of Joy ardently embraces the complexities of human emotions and life experiences, masterfully creating a cinematic world that resonates with audiences on a profound level. The movie's outstanding performances, captivating cinematography, and evocative storytelling all contribute to its magnificence as a film that celebrates the joy and resilience of the human spirit. A Symphony of Joy is a relentless, positive force in the world of cinema, taking viewers on a life-affirming journey that reminds us all of life's undeniable beauty and our own capacity to overcome trials with hope and grace.

prompt:
Answer the following question: Read the following paragraph and extract the answer for the question: What is the common English name of the animal that has eight subspecies?  The hartebeest (; Alcelaphus buselaphus), also known as kongoni, is an African antelope. Eight subspecies have been described, including two sometimes considered to be independent species. A large antelope, the hartebeest stands just over 1 m (3.3 ft) at the shoulder, and has a typical head-and-body length of 200 to 250 cm (79 to 98 in). The weight ranges from 100 to 200 kg (220 to 440 lb). It has a particularly elongated forehead and oddly shaped horns, short neck, and pointed ears. Its legs, which often have black markings, are unusually long. The coat is generally short and shiny. Coat colour varies by the subspecies, from the sandy brown of the western hartebeest to the chocolate brown of the Swayne's hartebeest. Both sexes of all subspecies have horns, with those of females being more slender. Horns can reach lengths of 45–70 cm (18–28 in). Apart from its long face, the large chest and the sharply sloping back differentiate the hartebeest from other antelopes. Gregarious animals, hartebeest form herds of 20 to 300 individuals. They are very alert and non-aggressive. They are primarily grazers, with their diets consisting mainly of grasses. Mating in hartebeest takes place throughout the year with one or two peaks, and depends upon the subspecies and local factors. Both males and females reach sexual maturity at one to two years of age. Gestation is eight to nine months long, after which a single calf is born. Births usually peak in the dry season. The lifespan is 12 to 15 years.
Answer:
response: The common English name of the animal that has eight subspecies is hartebeest.

prompt: How is "The next item is the debate on the following reports:" said in Finnish?
response:
In Finnish, the phrase "The next item is the debate on the following reports:" can be translated as "Seuraavana asiana on keskustelu seuraavista mietinnöistä:". Let's break down the translation for a better understanding of the sentence structure and vocabulary in Finnish:

- "Seuraavana asiana" means "the next item" or "the next matter". In this case, "seuraavana" is an adverb meaning "next", and "asiana" is a noun meaning "item" or "matter". 

- "on" is a verb meaning "is". In this context, it is used as an auxiliary verb to link the subject to the object or complement.

- "keskustelu" is a noun that means "debate" or "discussion". It is used here to indicate that a debate will be taking place on the following reports.

- "seuraavista" is an adjective meaning "following" or "next". It implies that the reports being referred to are the ones coming up next.

- "mietinnöistä" is a noun in the plural form, meaning "reports" or "evaluations". In this context, it refers to the reports that will be the subject of the debate.

So when mentioned together in the Finnish sentence "Seuraavana asiana on keskustelu seuraavista mietinnöistä:", it translates to "The next item is the debate on the following reports:".

prompt:
U.S. expels Venezuelan diplomat in Miami

By the CNN Wire Staff

updated 12:33 PM EST, Sun January 8, 2012

Washington (CNN) -- Venezuela's consul general in Miami has been declared to be persona non grata and must leave the United States, a State Department spokesman said Sunday.

Spokesman William Ostick declined to comment on specific details behind the decision to expel Livia Acosta Noguera, who has headed Venezuela's consulate in Miami since March 2011.

The Venezuelan Embassy in Washington was informed of the decision Friday, the spokesman said in a written statement, and the State Department said Acosta must depart the United States by Tuesday.

It was unclear Sunday whether she remained in the United States.

Last month, a group of American lawmakers said they had "grave concerns" about Acosta and called for an investigation after the Spanish-language TV channel Univision aired a documentary alleging that she was among a group of Venezuelan and Iranian diplomats who expressed interest in an offer from a group of Mexican hackers to infiltrate the websites of the White House, the FBI, the Pentagon and U.S. nuclear plants.

The evidence that the plot was real, according to Univision, are secret recordings with diplomats who ask questions about what the hackers can do and promise to send information to their governments.

Univision interviewed a purported Mexican whistle-blower -- a student at the National Autonomous University of Mexico named Juan Carlos Munoz Ledo. The student told Univision he was recruited by a leftist professor who wanted to wage cyberattacks on the United States and its allies.

Munoz told Univision he secretly recorded a meeting in 2008 with Acosta, who was then the cultural attache of the Venezuelan Embassy in Mexico. According to a recording Univision aired as part of its report, Acosta is heard saying that she can send the information gathered by the hackers straight to Venezuelan President Hugo Chavez.

Chavez has called the report "lies."

One of the Iranian diplomats told Univision that although he, indeed, was presented with a hacking plot by the Mexican group, he turned it down, in part because he thought they were CIA agents.

In a letter to U.S. Secretary of State Hillary Clinton last month, Rep. Ileana Ros-Lehtinen, Rep. David Rivera, Rep. Mario Diaz-Balart and Rep. Albio Sires asked the State Department to require Acosta's "immediate departure" from the United States if the Univision report proved true.

Last month a State Department spokesman said the United States did not know about the alleged plot, but that it found the Univision allegations "very disturbing."

However, "we don't have any information, at this point, to corroborate it," State Department spokesman Mark Toner said.

CNN's Jill Dougherty, Juan Carlos Lopez and Mariano Castillo contributed to this report.

Most popular stories right now

Write a one or two sentence summary.
response: The United States has asked a Venezuelan diplomat in Miami to leave the country. This happened because some people think she was involved in a plan to hack important websites in the United States.

prompt:
Charles Sanders Peirce (, like "purse"; September 10, 1839 - April 19, 1914) was an American philosopher, logician, mathematician, and scientist who is sometimes known as "the father of pragmatism". He was educated as a chemist and employed as a scientist for 30 years. Today he is appreciated largely for his contributions to logic, mathematics, philosophy, scientific methodology, and semiotics, and for his founding of pragmatism. An innovator in mathematics, statistics, philosophy, research methodology, and various sciences, Peirce considered himself, first and foremost, a logician.

In 1879, Peirce was appointed Lecturer in logic at Johns Hopkins University, which had strong departments in a number of areas that interested him, such as philosophy (Royce and Dewey completed their PhDs at Hopkins), psychology (taught by G. Stanley Hall and studied by Joseph Jastrow, who coauthored a landmark empirical study with Peirce), and mathematics (taught by J. J. Sylvester, who came to admire Peirce's work on mathematics and logic). His Studies in Logic by Members of the Johns Hopkins University (1883) contained works by himself and Allan Marquand, Christine Ladd, Benjamin Ives Gilman, and Oscar Howard Mitchell, several of whom were his graduate students. Peirce's nontenured position at Hopkins was the only academic appointment he ever held.  Brent documents something Peirce never suspected, namely that his efforts to obtain academic employment, grants, and scientific respectability were repeatedly frustrated by the covert opposition of a major Canadian-American scientist of the day, Simon Newcomb. Peirce's efforts may also have been hampered by what Brent characterizes as his difficult personality. Conversely, Keith Devlin believes that Peirce's work was too far ahead of his time to be appreciated by the academic establishment of the day and that this played a large role in his inability to obtain a tenured position.  Peirce's personal life undoubtedly worked against his professional success. After his first wife, Harriet Melusina Fay ("Zina"), left him in 1875, Peirce, while still legally married, became involved with Juliette, whose last name, given variously as Froissy and Pourtalai, and nationality (she spoke French) remains uncertain. When his divorce from Zina became final in 1883, he married Juliette. That year, Newcomb pointed out to a Johns Hopkins trustee that Peirce, while a Hopkins employee, had lived and traveled with a woman to whom he was not married; the ensuing scandal led to his dismissal in January 1884. Over the years Peirce sought academic employment at various universities without success. He had no children by either marriage.

Using a quote from the above article, answer the following question: when was the university founded?
response: The quote from the above article does not provide information on when the university was founded.

prompt:
Article: Each sprayer is different, so read the instruction manual before starting. Usually, you fill the sprayer's bucket with your chosen paint. You then attach the sprayer pump to the bucket. Sprayers usually come with different nozzles depending on which part of the fence you're painting, so choose the correct nozzle to begin.  Unless you're only painting a small portion of the fence, choose the largest nozzle first. As you continue painting and need to get into cracks and crevices, use smaller, more precise nozzles as needed. Remember to use an oil-based fence that is safe for wood and exterior use and choose a day that is not very windy. Use horizontal strokes for horizontal panels and vertical strokes for vertical ones. Allow the primer to dry before proceeding. Drying times vary, so refer to the instructions on the can of primer for precise drying times. Keep your nozzle about six to eight inches away from the fence. Use a steady back and forth motion to spray your fence. For horizontal panels, move up and down. For verticals ones, move back and forth.  After spraying down one panel, go over your work at a perpendicular line of about 90 degrees. This leaves a crisscross pattern on your fence that eliminates streaks. Make sure not to make arcs at the ends of each stroke. This will spray paint in unwanted places. After your paint dries, examine your fence. Decide whether or not a second coat is necessary. If you chose a quality paint, you can probably get by with a single coat. However, if your paint is a little thin, add an extra coat after the first 1 dries. Check your paint's instructions to see how long it takes to dry. Most paints need to dry overnight.
What is a summary of what this article is about?
response: The article provides a detailed guide on how to properly paint a fence using a sprayer. It emphasizes the importance of reading the instruction manual and selecting the right nozzle for the task. The article also suggests using an oil-based paint suitable for wood and exterior use and painting on a non-windy day. The correct painting technique is outlined, including how to make horizontal and vertical strokes depending on the panels, maintaining the right distance from the fence, and crossing strokes to eliminate streaks. Lastly, the drying time and the need for a second coat are discussed, with the recommendation to check paint instructions for specific drying times.

prompt:
Please answer the following question: Question: "What would help the Ottomans reach their ultimate goal?"  Context: "The Ottoman economic mind was closely related to the basic concepts of state and society in the Middle East in which the ultimate goal of a state was consolidation and extension of the ruler's power, and the way to reach it was to get rich resources of revenues by making the productive classes prosperous. The ultimate aim was to increase the state revenues without damaging the prosperity of subjects to prevent the emergence of social disorder and to keep the traditional organization of the society intact."  Answer:
A:
response:
In order to help the Ottomans reach their ultimate goal of consolidating and extending the ruler's power, while maintaining the prosperity of the productive classes and preventing social disorder, several strategies and policies can be implemented:

1. Efficient tax system: Developing and implementing a fair and efficient tax system would ensure that revenues can be increased without causing undue burden on the productive classes. This would encourage economic growth and provide the necessary resources for the state to expand its power.

2. Promoting trade and commerce: Facilitating international and domestic trade through the establishment of trade routes, encouraging innovation, and reducing barriers to commerce would help increase the prosperity of the productive classes and state revenues. This could include ensuring the security and maintenance of trade routes, as well as fostering diplomatic relations with potential trading partners.

3. Investment in infrastructure: The state needs to invest in the development and maintenance of infrastructure to support economic growth. This may include projects such as building roads, bridges, ports, and irrigation systems to facilitate trade and improve agricultural productivity. A well-developed infrastructure would enable the productive classes to flourish and contribute to the overall prosperity of the society.

4. Education and skill development: Investing in the education and training of the population would enable the Ottomans to develop a skilled workforce capable of supporting economic growth and stability. This could be achieved through offering scholarships, establishing educational institutions, and promoting technical and vocational training programs.

5. Supporting agricultural and industrial growth: Encouraging innovation and the adoption of modern agricultural and industrial practices would ensure the consistent growth of the productive classes, contributing to the stability and prosperity of the society. State support for new technologies and best practices would help improve productivity and output, further increasing revenues.

6. Maintaining social order and stability: One of the key aspects of Ottoman society was its hierarchical structure. Maintaining this structure and ensuring social stability would involve balancing the interests of various social groups, resolving disputes fairly, and enforcing laws consistently. A stable and well-functioning society would be more conducive to economic growth and revenue generation.

7. Effective administration and governance: To achieve the ultimate goal of consolidating and extending the ruler's power, the Ottomans need to have an effective and organized administration, which can manage state affairs and revenues efficiently. This would include the establishment of institutions, appointment of capable officials, and implementation of laws and regulations.

By implementing these strategies, the Ottomans could achieve their ultimate goal of consolidating and extending the ruler's power while keeping the traditional organization of society intact and maintaining the prosperity and well-being of their subjects.
